posts.title: Playwright,微软浏览器自动化教程（二）
posts.text: Playwright,微软浏览器自动化教程（二）核心概念，建议结合第一节的内容具体理解 1、Browser这是一个浏览器实例，脚本运行需要首先打开浏览器实例 12# playwright.brwoser_type.action(**kwargs)可以理解为指定浏览器内核browser = playwright.chromium.launch(channel="chrome",headless=False) 123456# launch是最常用的一个函数，他有大量的参数,这里介绍常用的的headless 是否显示GUI，默认是TRUE不显示channel 指定浏览器版本，"chrome", "chrome-beta", "chrome-dev", "chrome-canary",proxy 浏览器代理设置timeout 等待超时时间，默认30000ms（30s）slow_mo 减慢操作速度，浮点型，一边可以看清楚操作 顺便说一下，playwright的所有操作都有自动等待的功能，时间都是30s 2、Browser contexts这个是独立的浏览器，隐身对话，意思是每一个Beowser contexts都是独立的，互相之间没有关系，等于说全都是新装的浏览器。 1234# 根据浏览器内核创建浏览器context = browser.new_context(accept_downloads=False)# 创建新页面page = context.new_page() 2.1、browser.new_context1234567# browser.new_context的参数包括所有跟浏览器设置相关的# 可以理解为根据浏览器创建一个新的浏览器accept_downloads 是否下载所有附件，默认False不下载geolocation 设定经纬度user_agent 设定user agentviewport 设定页面大小，规格，例如1280*720offline 离线模式加载 2.2、context123456# context就是浏览器层面的操作context.new_page() 返回一个新页面context.pages 返回所有打开的页面[list]context.add_cookies([cookie_object1, cookie_object2]) 添加cookiecontext.cookies() 返回cookiecontext.wait_for_event(event, **kwargs) 等待event完成 3、Pages and frames一个 Browser contexts 有多个pages，一个 page 是一个单独的tab，或者弹出窗口。用于导航到url ，或者与页面交互，比如点击，输入文字等。一个 page 有多个 Frame （框架），框架内的操作无法通过page.**操作，只能通过page.Frame.func（）操作，但是通常在录制模式下，他会自动识别是否是框架内的操作，如果不懂怎么定位框架，那么可以使用录制模式来找。 3.1、Pages大部分操作都是在page层面的，所以page有最多的函数 12345678910111213from playwright.sync_api import sync_playwright# 这是一个创建页面，定位到指定链接，并截屏保存的例子def run(playwright): webkit = playwright.webkit browser = webkit.launch() context = browser.new_context() page = context.new_page() page.goto("https://example.com") page.screenshot(path="screenshot.png") browser.close()with sync_playwright() as playwright: run(playwright) 常用的函数有，一般看名字就知道是干嘛的 1234567891011121314151617181920212223242526page.click(selector, **kwargs)page.content() # 获取页面的htmlpage.screenshot(**kwargs)page.goto(url, **kwargs)page.pdf(**kwargs)page.reload(**kwargs)page.wait_for_timeout(timeout)page.get_attribute(selector, name, **kwargs)# page的expect_**函数需要注意# 这个类型的函数一般都伴随这with使用# 下面这个例子就是点击按钮后，改变了页面框架with page.expect_event("framenavigated") as event_info: page.click("button")frame = event_info.value#这样的还有很多，比如，大都用在交互的对象改变的情况下page.expect_file_chooser(**kwargs)page.expect_navigation(**kwargs)page.expect_popup(**kwargs)# 个人推荐注意这几个is的方法，在等待页面的时候很有用page.is_disabled/(selector, **kwargs)is_editable，is_enabled，is_hidden，is_visible# 还有一个特殊的方法page.locator(selector) # 定位页面元素，返回的是locator对象 3.2、Frameframe的操作大部分跟page一样，只不过frame是page下一级的，可以理解为在page里嵌套的一个小页面。但是还是有一点不一样。page里分为主框架和子框架，这里有一个框架树的例子,大家可以运行下试试。 1234567891011121314151617from playwright.sync_api import sync_playwrightdef run(playwright): firefox = playwright.firefox browser = firefox.launch() page = browser.new_page() page.goto("https://www.theverge.com") dump_frame_tree(page.main_frame, "") browser.close()def dump_frame_tree(frame, indent): print(indent + frame.name + '@' + frame.url) for child in frame.child_frames: dump_frame_tree(child, indent + " ")with sync_playwright() as playwright: run(playwright) 其方法大部分都与page一样，不在赘述，注意的是page.frame(**kwargs)，这个可以用来选择Frame，并返回Frame对象，所以对Frame的操作有一下两种方法。 123456# 直接定位Frame操作page.frame(name="frame-name").click('text=hello')#返回Frame对象操作frame = page.frame(name="frame-name")frame.click('text=hello') 4、SelectorsPlaywright可以通过css,XPath,HTML等选择元素，像id,data-test-id，或者像上面演示的，通过text内容。这里有一些例子 12345678910111213# Using data-test-id= selector enginepage.click('data-test-id=foo')# CSS and XPath selector engines are automatically detectedpage.click('div')page.click('//html/body/div')# Find node by text substringpage.click('text=Hello w')# 通过 >> 链接相同或不同的选择器# Click an element with text 'Sign Up' inside of a #free-month-promo.page.click('#free-month-promo >> text=Sign Up') 我推荐使用浏览器的开发者模式来寻找选择器： 5、Auto-waiting所有的操作都会等待元素可见，或者可操作之后才会进行，也就是自带等待时间，但是如果要自己加等待的话不推荐使用time.sleep(5)，而是用page.wait_for_timeout(5000)。这里也可以使用page的wait操作: 123456page.wait_for_event(event, **kwargs)page.wait_for_function(expression, **kwargs)page.wait_for_load_state(**kwargs)page.wait_for_selector(selector, **kwargs)page.wait_for_timeout(timeout)page.wait_for_url(url, **kwargs) 6、Evaluation Argument像 page.evaluate(expression, **kwargs) 这样的剧作家评估方法采用单个可选参数。 此参数可以是 Serializable 值和 JSHandle 或 ElementHandle 实例的混合。 句柄会自动转换为它们所代表的值。 123456789101112131415161718192021222324252627282930313233343536373839# A primitive value.page.evaluate('num => num', 42)# An array.page.evaluate('array => array.length', [1, 2, 3])# An object.page.evaluate('object => object.foo', { 'foo': 'bar' })# A single handle.button = page.query_selector('button')page.evaluate('button => button.textContent', button)# Alternative notation using elementHandle.evaluate.button.evaluate('(button, from) => button.textContent.substring(from)', 5)# Object with multiple handles.button1 = page.query_selector('.button1')button2 = page.query_selector('.button2')page.evaluate("""o => o.button1.textContent + o.button2.textContent""", { 'button1': button1, 'button2': button2 })# Object destructuring works. Note that property names must match# between the destructured object and the argument.# Also note the required parenthesis.page.evaluate(""" ({ button1, button2 }) => button1.textContent + button2.textContent""", { 'button1': button1, 'button2': button2 })# Array works as well. Arbitrary names can be used for destructuring.# Note the required parenthesis.page.evaluate(""" ([b1, b2]) => b1.textContent + b2.textContent""", [button1, button2])# Any non-cyclic mix of serializables and handles works.page.evaluate(""" x => x.button1.textContent + x.list[0].textContent + String(x.foo)""", { 'button1': button1, 'list': [button2], 'foo': None }) 参考文章:参考链接

posts.title: Playwright,微软浏览器自动化教程（一）
posts.text: Playwright,微软浏览器自动化教程（一）快速开始 1、简介Playwright 支持大部分的语言，Node.js, python, Java, .Net, 并且支持谷歌，火狐等浏览器，跨平台，并且支持移动端的模拟，可以很方便的录制脚本。并且可以使用同步或异步的打开方式。我们先从同步开始。 2、快速开始2.1、安装PIP123pip install --upgrade pippip install playwrightplaywright install 2.2、录制脚本推荐新手首先使用提供的录制功能，自己录制一个脚本，然后对着生成的代码，这样会对这个的使用流程有一个大概的理解。使用下面的命令可以快速录制一个脚本。 1playwright codegen wikipedia.org 123456-o <file name> 保存的文件名--target <language> 生成的脚本语言，像javascript, python(默认) -b 指定浏览器 chromium（默认）, firefox--channel <channel> 指定浏览器版本"chrome","chrome-beta", "msedge-dev"--device <deviceName> 模拟设备，像 "iPhone 11" -h, --help 更多命令，请看帮助 3、脚本详解我们先从一个简单录制的脚本讲起，在生成脚本的同时，还自动生成了注释，可以说是非常方便，根据注释也可以帮助我们理解代码 123456789101112131415161718192021222324252627282930from playwright.sync_api import Playwright, sync_playwrightdef run(playwright: Playwright) -> None: # 首先实例化一个浏览器对象 browser = playwright.chromium.launch(headless=False) # 打开一个浏览器会话 context = browser.new_context() # 打开一个新页面 page = context.new_page() # Go to https://www.google.com.hk/?gws_rd=ssl page.goto("https://www.google.com.hk/?gws_rd=ssl") # Click [aria-label="搜索"] page.click("[aria-label=\"搜索\"]") # Fill [aria-label="搜索"] page.fill("[aria-label=\"搜索\"]", "playwright") # Press Enter # 这里是一个页面导航功能 # 点击元素可以出发导航，要求使用 page.expect_navigation(**kwargs) # 这里点击了搜索按钮，这样页面信息可以获取浏览器新的内容 with page.expect_navigation(): page.press("[aria-label=\"搜索\"]", "Enter") # 这里由于打开了新的页面，所以需要使用page.expect_popup()来获取新的页面，并且用as来操作新的页面 with page.expect_popup() as popup_info: page.click("text=Playwright: Fast and reliable end-to-end testing for modern ...") # 这里将新页面命名为page1，并将新的页面信息传给page1 page1 = popup_info.value # 关闭浏览器会话，和浏览器 context.close() browser.close()with sync_playwright() as playwright: run(playwright) 4、总结目前来看，这个录制功能是比较方便好用的，可以帮助我们快速理解代码但是缺点也很明显，这个录制功能无法进行循环操作，仅这一条就说明无法靠录制解决所有的自动化任务，除非你选择在外层进行循环，但那样会降低效率，并且从上面代码上来看，其自动定位的元素都是text，无法从网页根本上定位元素。下一节，我将介绍playwright的核心概念，来帮助理解整个的工作流程参考文章:playwright for python

posts.title: Playwright+Bs4爬取微信公众号文章链接
posts.text: 由于微信的公众号文章阅读体验过于差劲，而在找遍全网都没有找到可靠的微信rss之后，我打算自己写一个爬取微信公众号文章的脚本，结合playwright来降低爬取难度，对新手比较友好，可以不用分析请求，对我来说也是一个学习palywright的过程。 前言1、由于搜狗搜索只能看到最近十篇文章2、有找到过从网页端微信获取的，但是我的微信网页端登不上只能放弃3、还有了解过pywinauto的windows的自动化，但是已经用过playwright，还要花时间去学习4、找到有利用公众号后台的超链接进行爬取的方法因此决定使用playwright来解决这个问题 1、playwright录制脚本首先使用playwright录制脚本，将大概的过程进行录制:playwright codegen -o wehcet_fetch.py https://mp.weixin.qq.com/在录制前要想好大概的步骤，以及后面需要进行循环的翻页操作 2、设置循环由于在后台页面只要在超链接里操作就可以，所以只需要设置：1、更换公众号名字的循环2、同一个公众号文章翻页循环 通过这两步即将整个的流程处理完成了下面就是run()函数，传入的参数分别是： 12name: 公众号名字列表all_artical: 储存文章的列表 1234567891011121314151617181920212223242526272829303132333435363738394041424344454647def run(playwright: Playwright,name,all_artical) -> None: browser = playwright.chromium.launch(headless=False) context = browser.new_context(accept_downloads=True) # Open new page page = context.new_page() # with page.expect_download() as download_info: # Go to https://mp.weixin.qq.com/ page.goto("https://mp.weixin.qq.com/") # Click text=图文消息 文字消息 视频消息 音频消息 图片消息 转载 >> svg with page.expect_popup() as popup_info: page.click("text=图文消息 文字消息 视频消息 音频消息 图片消息 转载 >> svg") page1 = popup_info.value # 公众号数量，用来定位all_artical num = 0 # Click text=超链接 page1.click("text=超链接") # 遍历所有名字，分别爬取 for item in name: # 保存在一个列表中的一个列表中 all_artical.append([]) # Click text=选择其他公众号 page1.click("text=选择其他公众号") # Click [placeholder="输入文章来源的公众号名称或微信号，回车进行搜索"] page1.click("[placeholder=\"输入文章来源的公众号名称或微信号，回车进行搜索\"]") # Fill [placeholder="输入文章来源的公众号名称或微信号，回车进行搜索"] page1.fill("[placeholder=\"输入文章来源的公众号名称或微信号，回车进行搜索\"]", item) # Click [placeholder="输入文章来源的公众号名称或微信号，回车进行搜索"] page1.click("[placeholder=\"输入文章来源的公众号名称或微信号，回车进行搜索\"]") # Press Enter page1.press("[placeholder=\"输入文章来源的公众号名称或微信号，回车进行搜索\"]", "Enter") # Click text=阮一峰的网络日志 微信号：ruanyf-blog page1.click("text=订阅号") time.sleep(3) # Click text=下一页 # 当到最后一页时，没有下一页，退出循环 while True: if page1.is_editable( "#vue_app > div.weui-desktop-link-dialog > div.weui-desktop-dialog__wrp > div > div.weui-desktop-dialog__bd > div.link_dialog_panel > form:nth-child(1) > div:nth-child(4) > div > div > div.weui-desktop-media__list-wrp > div > div"): # 获取网页源码，使用bs4分析，提取链接,返回文章数量 numbers = artical_save(page1, num) if numbers<5: break else: page1.click("text = 下一页") time.sleep(random.random()*10) continue 这个函数中需要注意的是：1、大的循环的设定位置在打开超链接之后，点击选择其他公众号之前2、小的翻页循环设定在搜索公众号之后，循环下一页3、判断是否到最后一页，由于我目前没有找到可行的方法，只能使用判断最后一页的文章个数小于五来跳出循环，虽然问题很大，但我就赌他最后一页不是五个QAQ。 3、总结3.1、目前的问题1、最后一页的判断方法有问题2、由于微信公众号的限制，导致翻页过快，系统会封禁一段时间，所以需要将翻页时间设定较长时间，但是经过我的实验，在结束第一个60页的公众号后，到第二个还是会出现系统错误的问题，无法翻页，此问题目前还未解决。3、没有设置自动登录。4、playwright应该有可以直接获取页面信息的方法，但目前我还没有找到，只能通过BeautifulSoup来分析页面. 最后的完整源码在我的GitHub上，欢迎下载。 参考文章:参考链接

posts.title: Python-argprase命令行选项、参数和子命令解析
posts.text: 摘要argparse 模块可以让人轻松编写用户友好的命令行接口。程序定义它需要的参数，然后 argparse 将弄清如何从 sys.argv 解析出那些参数。argparse 模块还会自动生成帮助和使用手册，并在用户给程序传入无效参数时报出错误信息。 1、创建一个解析器使用argparse的第一步就是创建一个解析器对象，即ArgumentParser对象，这个对象有多个参数，我们一个一个来讲。 12345678910parser = argparse.ArgumentParser( prog='', # 程序名称 description='', # 在帮助文档前显示的文本 epilog='', # 在帮助文档后显示的文本 add_help=True, # 是否添加帮助选项，即-h，默认True usage='' # 设定usage中显示的文本，默认为：程序名称+-h )# 首先创建一个对象parser = argparse.ArgumentParser(usage="how to use"，prog='Name',description='Front description',epilog='Back description') 其中各个参数的对应位置如下图：在设置了usage之后，图中对应的就会变为：usage: how to use这些就是基本的常用参数。其他用法请参考官方文档。 2、为解析器添加参数添加参数使用add_argument()方法，我们将逐个讲解，因为这些都比较重要： 12345678910111213ArgumentParser.add_argument( name or flags... # 一个位置参数，或者指定名字的参数 # 即添加的此参数的名字 [, action] # [, nargs] [, const] [, default] [, type] [, choices] [, required] [, help] [, metavar] [, dest]) 2.1、Name or flags首先我们要搞清楚，这个add_argument() 函数到底添加的是什么。为什么第一个参数不带括号，后面的却带。 2.1.1、类比函数传参就像函数传参一样，一个程序不可能只传入一个数据，在函数参数里有两种常用的传参方式：关键字参数，默认参数 1234567891011def printinfo( name, age = 35 )# 这里 name 就是关键字参数# age 自带默认值，就是默认参数def printinfo( name, gander, age = 35 ): print ("名字: ", name) print ("性别: ", gander) print ("年龄: ", age)printinfo( "何小岳" ,"男")# 名字: 何小岳# 性别: 男# 年龄: 35 但是如果将传入的参数改变位置，那么结果就也会变，这就是位置传参，函数根据输入的数据的位置传入参数名字: 男 性别: 何小岳 年龄: 35而带有默认值的名字就只能通过指定参数的方法传入 123printinfo( age=50, name="何小岳" )# 名字: 何小岳# 年龄: 50 2.1.2、add_argument()传参因此，与函数传参相同，这里传入的参数也是分为位置传参，和指定参数传入。而与之不同的是：1、函数传参不能限制传入的类型，也就是唯一的限制条件就是默认值2、argparse 传参则可以通过后续的选项来设置限制 name即我们每用 add 一次，就会设置一个参数，例如： 1234567# 针对 add_argument() 的第一个参数 name or flags # 其也是分为两种传参方式，位置，和指定名称parser.add_argument('first')parser.add_argument('second')args = parser.parse_args()print(args.first+args.second) python .\argparse_learn.py 1 212 这里就将输入的连个字符串连接了起来，是通过位置传参的方式如果输入 -h 就会发现在 usage 中，两个参数的顺序是按添加的顺序显示的usage: My argparse [-h] first second flags这个就是指定名字传参了 12parser.add_argument('--first')parser.add_argument('--second') 如果将上面的两个参数改为这样，再次以同样的方式输入的话就会报错： python .\argparse_learn.py 1 2usage: My argparse [-h] [–first FIRST] [–second SECOND]My argparse: error: unrecognized arguments: 1 2 所以指定传参只能通过命令行来指定参数传递，比如这样： python .\argparse_learn.py –first 1 –second 212 但是这样还有个问题，即每次都要输入完整的单词，太长了怎么办 12345parser.add_argument('-f','--first')parser.add_argument('-s','--second')args = parser.parse_args()print(args.first+args.second) python .\argparse_learn.py -s 2 -f 332 这样再加一个 -f 一位的缩写即可通过短的名字来添加函数，需要特别注意的是：再 print 的时候，需要写全称，因为其中默认的变量名是全称。 -f FIRST, --first FIRST -s SECOND, --second SECOND 2.2 Action这个指的是将命令好参数与动作相关联，默认的是1.store –存储参数的值，上文中可以打印出参数就是因为这个参数2.sotre_const 这个通常和const结合使用，用来存储const命名参数指定的值即在命令行中通过const指定参数的值 12345parser.add_argument('-f','--first',action='store_const',const="10")parser.add_argument('-s','--second')args = parser.parse_args()print(args.first+args.second) 123456> python .\argparse_learn.py -s 2 -f102# 这时如果在指定参数的值就会报错> python .\argparse_learn.py -s 2 -f 10usage: My argparse [-h] [-f] [-s SECOND]My argparse: error: unrecognized arguments: 10 3.store_truestore_false这两个分别指定参数值为true和false 12345parser.add_argument('-f','--first',action='store_true')print(args.first)------> python .\argparse_learn.py -s 2False 4.append,储存列表 12345parser.add_argument('-f','--first',action='append')print(args)------> python .\argparse_learn.py -f 1 -f 2 -f 3Namespace(first=['1', '2', '3'], second=None) 5.append_const,储存const中的值，一般在多个参数需要在同一列表中存储常数时会有用。6.count,计算一个关键字参数出现的次数 parser.add_argument('-f','--first',action='count') python .\argparse_learn.py -fff3 2.3、Nargs这个参数可以使一个参数，一次添加多个值，变成可迭代对象 123456789101112131415161718N---- #（一个整数），命令中N个参数，聚集形成一个列表例：>>> parser.add_argument('-f', nargs=2)Namespace(first=['a', 'b'])------？---- #这个等于是函数传参中的 *args ，可选传参，另外使用这个即可解决上文中，使用 const 无法在传参的问题parser.add_argument('-f','--first',nargs="?",const= 10)> python .\argparse_learn.py -f 1Namespace(first='1')> python .\argparse_learn.py -fNamespace(first=10)------* and +---- # 所有参数都聚集到一个列表中,* 和 + 是一个作用，结果也相同parser.add_argument('-f','--first',nargs="*"/"+")> python .\argparse_learn.py -f 1 2 3Namespace(first=['1', '2', '3'])不同的是，当输入为空时，+ 会报错，* 不会 2.4、const通常在store_const, append_const中必须给出参数，其余默认为None。是常数值。 2.5 defult指定在命令行参数未给出的默认值。提供 default=argparse.SUPPRESS 导致命令行参数未出现时没有属性被添加。 2.6、type指定输入类型，通常解析器默认读入的是字符串类型的，如果需要整数等其余类型需要指定type。例如：int,float,ascii,ord等。 2.7、chorice指定参数只能从一个容器中选择，例如： 12345parser.add_argument('-f','--first',choices=[110,120,119])> python .\argparse_learn.py -f 100usage: My argparse [-h] [-f {110,120,119}] [-s SECOND]My argparse: error: argument -f/--first: invalid choice: '100' (choose from 110, 120, 119) 2.8、required指定参数为必要参数：required=True 2.9、help这是当在命令行加入 -h 参数时，出现在参数后面的解释。 12345678910111213parser.add_argument('-f','--first',choices=[110,120,119],help="learning")> python .\argparse_learn.py -husage: My argparse [-h] [-f {110,120,119}]Front descriptionoptional arguments: -h, --help show this help message and exit -f {110,120,119}, --first {110,120,119} learning #就是这里Back description 2.10、metavar这个参数的意思是，改变的参数显示名字。我们先看默认情况下： 1234567891011121314151617parser.add_argument('-f','--first',help="learning")args = parser.parse_args()print(args.first)> python .\argparse_learn.py -husage: My argparse [-h] [-f FIRST]Front descriptionoptional arguments: -h, --help show this help message and exit -f FIRST, --first FIRST learning# 这里两个参数的别名都是默认的FIRST，所以我们可以通过：# args.first 来访问参数的值> python .\argparse_learn.py -f 22 如果设定metavar值： 123456parser.add_argument('-f','--first',help="learning",,metavar="fff")# 这样其访问的名字就会变为fffoptional arguments: -h, --help show this help message and exit -f fff, --first fff learning 但是他只能改变显示名字，无法通过这个来访问元素，还是需要通过原来的值来访问。 12345678> python .\argparse_learn.py -f 22> python .\argparse_learn.py -f 2Traceback (most recent call last): File ".\argparse_learn.py", line 15, in <module> print(args.fff)AttributeError: 'Namespace' object has no attribute 'fff' 2.11、dest这个dest就是metavar的默认值，所以修改dest即可改变属性的名称。 1234567891011parser.add_argument('-f','--first',help="learning",metavar="fff",dest="new_name")print(args.first)> python .\argparse_learn.py -f 2AttributeError: 'Namespace' object has no attribute 'first'# 可以看到在我们更改dest后，已经无法通过first来访问属性print(args.new_name)> python .\argparse_learn.py -f 22# 通过new_name即可访问属性 3、parse_args这是最后一步，这个函数用来解析命令行中的字符串，并将其传入命名空间。 123456789101112# 总结一下# 第一步，创建解析器parser = argparse.ArgumentParser(prog='My argparse',description='Front description',epilog='Back description')# 第二步，添加参数parser.add_argument('-f','--first',help="learning",metavar="fff",dest="new_name")# 第三步，解读命令行args = parser.parse_args()# 最后通过args即可操作输入的参数了# 就像个我上面打印的用法一样，通过属性名，访问属性值 这既是大部分的内容，其余少量的内容，请翻阅官方文档。 参考文章:参考链接

posts.title: Python数据类型之Collections容器数据类型
posts.text: Python 数据类型学习记录—-collections–容器类型 这个模块实现了特定目标的容器，以提供Python标准内建容器 dict , list , set , 和 tuple 的替代选择。 1、ChainMap对象可将多个字典，或者其他映射组合在一起，创建一个单独的，可更新的视图。如果传入参数为空，则为默认的空字典。如下所示： 12345678910baseline = {'music': 'bach', 'art': 'rembrandt'}adjustments = {'art': 'van gogh', 'opera': 'carmen'}a =collections.ChainMap(adjustments, baseline)print(a.maps[0])print(list(a.maps[0]))print(a.maps[1])------{'art': 'van gogh', 'opera': 'carmen'}['art', 'opera']{'music': 'bach', 'art': 'rembrandt'} 2、Counter对象一个计数器工具，提供快速和方便的计数。一个Counter是一个集合，元素像字典键一样存储，计数存储为值。 1234567891011# 可从可迭代对象，或mapping中初始化c = Counter(iterable/mapping)# 通过字典接口调用，返回元素的个数，没有则返回0c = Counter(['eggs', 'ham'])c['bacon']0# 设置元素为0，不会自动移除，需通过del来删除元素c['sausage'] = 0del c['sausage'] 除了字典还有其他三个方法 elements()返回一个迭代器，，每个元素重复出现指定的次数。1234c = Counter(a=4, b=2, c=0, d=-2)sorted(c.elements())['a', 'a', 'a', 'a', 'b', 'b'] most_common([n])返回一个列表，其中包含 n 个最常见的元素及出现次数，按常见程度由高到低排序。 如果 n 被省略或为 None，most_common() 将返回计数器中的 所有元素。123Counter('abracadabra').most_common(3)[('a', 5), ('b', 2), ('r', 2)] subtract([iterable-or-mapping])从 迭代对象 或 映射对象 减去元素。像 dict.update() 但是是减去，而不是替换。输入和输出都可以是0或者负数。123456c = Counter(a=4, b=2, c=0, d=-2)d = Counter(a=1, b=2, c=3, d=4)c.subtract(d)cCounter({'a': 3, 'b': 0, 'c': -3, 'd': -6}) 3、deque对象返回一个双向队列，从左到右初始化。方法有： append(x)#添加 x 到右端。 appendleft(x)添加 x 到左端。 clear()移除所有元素，使其长度为0. copy()创建一份浅拷贝。 count(x)计算 deque 中元素等于 x 的个数。 index(x[, start[, stop]])返回 x 在 deque 中的位置（在索引 start 之后，索引 stop 之前）。 返回第一个匹配项，如果未找到则引发 ValueError。 insert(i, x)在位置 i 插入 x 。 pop()移去并且返回一个元素，deque 最右侧的那一个。 如果没有元素的话，就引发一个 IndexError。 popleft()移去并且返回一个元素，deque 最左侧的那一个。 如果没有元素的话，就引发 IndexError。 remove(value)移除找到的第一个 value。 如果没有的话就引发 ValueError。 reverse()将deque逆序排列。返回 None 。 4、UserList对象这个类封装了列表对象。它是一个有用的基础类，对于你想自定义的类似列表的类，可以继承和覆盖现有的方法，也可以添加新的方法。这样我们可以对列表添加新的行为。 5、UserString对象UserString 类是用作字符串对象的外包装。对这个类的需求已部分由直接创建 str 的子类的功能所替代；不过，这个类处理起来更容易，因为底层的字符串可以作为属性来访问。 参考文章:参考链接

posts.title: 在linux上搭建syncplay服务，实现远程异地同步看电影
posts.text: syncplayer安装简单快捷，只要有一个服务器即可实现与朋友同步观影 1、首先需要一个有公网ip的服务器，并在防火墙中打开你将要使用的端口2、在github上下载源码,并上传到服务器中3、链接到服务器开始部署 进入 syncplay 文件夹，执行以下命令sudo make install-server 安装python3， 以及要求的库yum install -y python3pip install Twistedpip install PySide2 4、运行服务器 使用下面的命令运行,在第一次运行时会提醒你下次运行带上 salt 参数。syncplay-server --password myPassword --port 4567 --salt XXXXXXXX --motd-file /opt/syncplay/motd.txt 将服务设置为后台运行[root@localhost ~]# nohup syncplay-server --password myPassword --port 4567 --motd-file /opt/syncplay/motd.txt --salt XXXXXXXX >/dev/null 2>&1 &[1] 48045 服务器命令行开关（Syncplay 1.5.2+） –port [port] – 使用规定的端口而不是默认端口。 –isolate-room– 如果指定，则启用“房间隔离”。这意味着查看者将无法看到其他房间中用户的信息。推荐公共服务器使用此功能，但不适用于小型私人服务器。 –password [password]– 将 Syncplay 服务器的访问权限限制为只有在连接到服务器时使用此密码的人。建议私有服务器使用此功能，但公共服务器不需要此功能。默认情况下，密码为空（即没有密码限制）。不要使用您在其他任何地方使用的密码！您还可以通过 SYNCPLAY_PASSWORD 环境变量指定此值。 –salt [salt] –用于生成受控房间密码的随机盐字符串 – 需要相同才能使受控房间密码在服务器实例之间工作。您还可以通过 SYNCPLAY_SALT 环境变量指定此值。 –motd-file [filepath] – 从中获取 motd 的文件路径 –disable-ready - 禁用就绪指示器功能 –disable-chat – 禁用聊天功能 –max-chat-message-length – 聊天消息的最大长度（字符数） –max-username-length – 用户名的最大长度（字符数） –stats-db-file [filepath] – 使用提供的 SQLite db 文件启用服务器统计信息 –tls [path]– 使用指定路径上的证书启用 TLS。有关更多说明，请参阅Syncplay TLS 指南。此功能仅在 Syncplay >= 1.6.3 中可用。 5、在客户端下载软件，并连接服务器输入对应的地址，密码。 需要注意的是，这里 path to media player 支持的播放器有 MPC-HC, MPC-BE, VLC, mpv and mplayer2。 MPV是最推荐的，这里附上下载地址连上之后，就会出现两个框：左侧可以使用url，或者本地的视频直接拖入，右侧则是一些日志输出，已经房间内的观众。至此教程结束。 参考文章:参考链接

posts.title: IDL数据处理之地表变化检测(NDVI)
posts.text: 摘要通过NDVI的变化检测土地覆盖的变化南安普顿大学，地理信息与环境专业，遥感IDL编程第二次作业 1、代码结构 Landsat卫星影像读取 NDVI计算 使用NDVI差值监测变化区域 对变化区域进行可视化展示，并计算变化比率 2、输入数据本次用到的是一个地区1992，2001，2006，2010四个年份的Landsat卫星影像数据。 3、变化检测理论支持 The method I choose is to calculate the difference of Normalized Difference Vegetation Index(NDVI) between two years. And calculate the threshold to define the change/no changing area. Mancino referred this technique(Mancino, Nolè, Ripullone and Ferrara, 2014). First, we calculated the NDVI of each year image using the RED and NIR bands. Second, calculate the difference of two years NDVI(ΔNDVI). Then using a threshold calculated as μ ± n·σ; μ is the mean of ΔNDVI and σ is standard deviation and n use 1 in this method. The threshold defines three regions of the ΔNDVI. The right and the left is the changing area. The central is no change. 4、核心代码4.1 数据读取 由于landsat卫星影像又五个波段，所以在读入时需要指定维度为三，方便后续对不同波段的操作。波段顺序为蓝，绿，红，近红外，短波红外。1234567function readdata,file_name ; read all data img=read_binary(file_name,data_dims=[3500,2500,5],data_type=1) ; b,g,r,n,s return, img end 4.2 NDVI计算 这里需要讲数据转换为浮点， 以为ndvi值都是小于1。这里还判断输入的两个波段数据是否一致，否则报错。差值则直接将两个数据相减即可得到1234567891011121314151617181920212223function ndvi,red,nir ;calculate the ndvi red = float(red) nir = float(nir) LEN_RED = N_ELEMENTS(RED) LEN_NIR = N_ELEMENTS(NIR) IF LEN_RED NE LEN_NIR THEN BEGIN RETURN, 'WRONG VALUES' ENDIF ELSE BEGIN NDVI_ARR=FLTARR(3500,2500) ENDELSE NDVI_ARR=(NIR-red)/(NIR+red) help,NDVI_ARR return, NDVI_ARRendfunction detection_cal,img1,img2 ;calculate the difference bewteen two years' ndvi change= img1-img2 return,changeend 4.3 变化检测 通过计算平均值+/-标准差来设定阈值，并比较大小，来决定其增加或减少。下面的代码通过where来找出ndvi值减少的区域，并返回。并通过per将变化率计算结果传到全局变量中。1234567891011121314151617181920212223function detection, change,per,num ; find the reduce change ; use an new array to set the -NAN to 0 a = where(change gt min(change)) tmp=fltarr(3500,2500) tmp[a]=change[a] ; cal the threshold=mean+-sdev result = moment(tmp,MEAN=meanval,SDEV=sdev) thres=meanval+sdev thresp=meanval-sdev ; greater than threshold is reduce changes = where(change gt thres,npixels) ; less than threshold is increase changesplus = where(change lt thresp,npixelsp) ; cal the percent of recude, increase and total per[num]=float(npixelsp)/n_elements(change) per[num+5]=float(npixels)/n_elements(change) per[num+10]=float(npixels+npixelsp)/n_elements(change) return, changesend 5、结果展示 NDVI图 相邻年份减少变化图 总的变化图 参考文章: Mancino, G., Nolè, A., Ripullone, F. and Ferrara, A., 2014. Landsat TM imagery and NDVI differencing to detect vegetation change: assessing natural forest expansion in Basilicata, southern Italy. iForest - Biogeosciences and Forestry, 7(2), pp.75-84.

posts.title: IDL遥感数据处理之叶绿素，叶子含水量与反射率的关系
posts.text: 摘要从文件中读取数据，并可视化分析叶绿素，叶子含水量与反射率的关系南安普顿大学，地理信息与环境专业，遥感IDL编程第一次作业 可视化分析叶绿素，叶子含水量与反射率的关系 从不同的数据存储方式中，读取数据，并使用plot进行可视化。 单个文件中读取全部数据 多个文件中读取不同波段的数据12345678910111213141516171819202122232425262728293031323334353637383940414243444546474849505152535455565758596061626364656667function readdata,file_name; Functions for reading filesdata = read_ascii(file_name)data = data.field1[*,*]return, dataendpro assessment1;reflectance of Chlorophyll changescd, 'F:\OneDrive - University of Southampton\southampton\sems1\programme RS IDL\assessment1'data1=readdata("Leaf_Reflectance_Different_ChlorophyllContent.dat");help,data1print,'-------------------'; Extract different chlorophyll columnswavelength = data1[0,*]chlorophyll_17 = data1[1,*]chlorophyll_25_5 = data1[2,*]chlorophyll_34 = data1[3,*]chlorophyll_42_5 = data1[4,*]chlorophyll_51 = data1[5,*]chlorophyll_59_5 = data1[6,*]chlorophyll_68 = data1[7,*]; draw plotp1 = PLOT(wavelength,chlorophyll_17, XTITLE='wavelength', YTITLE='reflectance', TITLE='reflectance of Chlorophyll changes', COLOR='red', Linestyle=0, DIM=[600,400], MARGIN=0.1, /OVERPLOT, NAME='chlorophyll_17')p2 = PLOT(wavelength,chlorophyll_25_5, XTITLE='wavelength', YTITLE='reflectance', TITLE='reflectance of Chlorophyll changes', COLOR='blue', Linestyle=0, DIM=[600,400], MARGIN=0.1, /OVERPLOT,NAME='chlorophyll_25_5')p3 = PLOT(wavelength,chlorophyll_34, XTITLE='wavelength', YTITLE='reflectance', TITLE='reflectance of Chlorophyll changes', COLOR='green', Linestyle=0, DIM=[600,400], MARGIN=0.1, /OVERPLOT,NAME='chlorophyll_34')p4 = PLOT(wavelength,chlorophyll_42_5, XTITLE='wavelength', YTITLE='reflectance', TITLE='reflectance of Chlorophyll changes', COLOR='yellow', Linestyle=0, DIM=[600,400], MARGIN=0.1, /OVERPLOT,NAME='chlorophyll_42_5')p5 = PLOT(wavelength,chlorophyll_51, XTITLE='wavelength', YTITLE='reflectance', TITLE='reflectance of Chlorophyll changes', COLOR='black', Linestyle=0, DIM=[600,400], MARGIN=0.1, /OVERPLOT,NAME='chlorophyll_51')p6 = PLOT(wavelength,chlorophyll_59_5, XTITLE='wavelength', YTITLE='reflectance', TITLE='reflectance of Chlorophyll changes', COLOR='orange', Linestyle=0, DIM=[600,400], MARGIN=0.1, /OVERPLOT,NAME='chlorophyll_59_5')p7 = PLOT(wavelength,chlorophyll_68, XTITLE='wavelength', YTITLE='reflectance', TITLE='reflectance of Chlorophyll changes', COLOR='pink', Linestyle=0, DIM=[600,400], MARGIN=0.1, /OVERPLOT,NAME='chlorophyll_68')lg=legend(TARGET=[p1, p2,p3,p4,p5,p6,p7], POSITION=[0.9,0.9],/NORMAL)p1.Save, "reflectance_of_Chlorophyll_changes.png", BORDER=50, RESOLUTION=500p1.close; reflectance of Moisture changescd, 'F:\programme RS IDL\'file = file_search(); Put the water content, and the color in the vectormoisture_content = ["0_0", "0_004", "0_008", "0_012","0_016", "0_02", "0_024"]color = ["red","blue","green","yellow","pink","black","orange"]; Create an array of graphic pointersp=objarr(7); Draw the plotfor i=0, n_elements(file)-1 do begin data = readdata(file[i]) p[i] = PLOT(wavelength,data[1,*], XTITLE='wavelength', YTITLE='reflectance', TITLE='reflectance of Moisture changes', COLOR=color[i], Linestyle=0, DIM=[600,400], MARGIN=0.1, /OVERPLOT, NAME='moisture_'+moisture_content[i])endforlg=legend(TARGET=[p[0],p[1], p[2],p[3],p[4],p[5],p[6]], POSITION=[0.35,0.9],/NORMAL)p[0].save, "reflectance_of_Moisture_changes.png", BORDER=50, RESOLUTION=500p[0].closeend 参考文章:参考链接

posts.title: ASTER和SRTM，DEM对比
posts.text: 摘要南安普顿大学，地理信息与环境专业，Topographic Data Analysis Techniques and Applications第二次作业 Difference between DEM derived from ASTER and downloaded from USGS’s SRTM1. IntroductionIn many geographical information systems, a digital elevation model (DEM) is one of the most essential spatial datasets (GIS). It’s a digital set of ground elevation (spot height) for landscape depiction that’s either ordered or unordered (Zhou, 2017). DEMs are a valuable data source for a variety of Earth and environmental science applications. The Earth’s topography is critical for everything from flood and runoff hydrologic modelling to assessing air boundary layer friction (Jing et al., 2013). DEM also contributes to the high integrity of Global Positioning System (GPS) pseudo-range measurement corrections, especially in environments with urban canyons (Wani et al., 2021). The traditional approach to building the DEM is based on closed polygon traverses using total station traversing that begins and end at the same location on the ground surface. It is always used to convey the relatively small agricultural, forested and urban areas. A traverse is a group of line segments (traverse stations) with visible ends whose length and direction are established through observation. The surveyor picks a group of points placed at a topographic feature from each wire station (e.g., along a structure line). After a series of final tweaks and computations, DEM creation is accomplished (Florinsky, 2016). However, this method has some limitations. it cannot measure the place where the laser cannot reach. And it is difficult to measure surface elevation if any non-ground object exists in landslides detecting (Tsai et al., 2012). Or when the signal reaches the margins of an object, the accuracy may decrease. Because the reflected data comes from two separate locations, the coordinates will be calculated as an average, putting the point in the incorrect location (Mohammed, 2021). Global Navigation Satellite Systems (GNSS) is another way to generate the DEM. It uses satellites such as GPS and GLONASS to get the position of ground points. A GNSS receiver picks up radio signals from a constellation of satellites. To calculate the coordinates (x, y, z) of a ground location, measurements from at least four satellites are required (Florinsky, 2016). The real-time kinematic’s (RTK) accuracy can reach± 10cm by using carrier phase measurements. It needs two receivers, the stationary reference station and the moving station. Via a transmitting communication link, the reference receiver calculates and broadcasts pseudo-range corrections (PCR) and range rate correction (RCC) in real-time, while a moving station receives these adjustments with a receiving communication link to compute exact placement. RTK is applied in airborne, land surveys, drones or other sensor data (Wani et al., 2021). The restricted satellite vision, multipath effect, interferences, and other limitations can all reduce GNSS’ positioning performance (Margaria et al., 2014). In order to generate the DEM from the satellite images, it requires two or more images in the same area but from different directions which are called the stereo pairs (Jacobsen, 2003). From the stereo pairs, we reconstruct geometric parameters to calculate the all points position(x,y,z) by using the stereo correlation or image matching algorithm (Florinsky, 2016). Compared with other methods, the ground survey needs more effort and the laser scanning need expensive equipment, the GNSS can be influenced by the weather also need people to get there in person (Kayadibi, 2009). In that case, the satellite data source is a good choice in generating DEM with the lower price and easy to get the stereo image, such as the KFA-1000, SPOT, MOMS, IRS-1C/1D, ASTER, IKONOS, QuickBird and SRTM (Jacobsen, 2003). 2. Data and Methods2.1 Study areaThis study focuses on one region in America, the Rocky Mountains. The area is 3942 km2, elevation ranges from 1560 m to 3945 m, and covers approximately 62 by 62 km at 105° W and 38° N near. The mean elevation is 2534 m (Figure 2.1.1). Figure 2.1.1 study area ### 2.2 Data preparation * DEM extract from ASTER data using ENVI * SRTM DEM download from the USGS 1 arcsec/30 m In 1999, an advanced multispectral imager the advanced spaceborne thermal emission and reflection radiometer (ASTER) is launched onboard from the terra spacecraft. Aster has 14 bands and is of high spatial, spectral and radiometric resolution. ASTER contains two telescopes, one for looking down at the ground and the other for looking backwards. The ASTER can generate two types of level-1 data, level-A and level-B. In this practice, we use the level-A data. Level-A data contains geometric parameters and spacecraft information, because of that, we don’t need to deal with the GCP in the processing (Fujisada et al., 2005).For the Aster data, we use the ENVI classic 5.1 DEM extraction Wizard. Below is the brief process in that wizard. In defining the tie points, we choose automatic and then delete the error points to reduce the Y parallax under 10 pixels. ENVI will next compute the epipolar geometry and epipolar images that will be utilised to extract the DEM using the tie points. After specifying the DEM output projection and extraction parameters, we can get the output DEM. Figure 2.2.1 ASTER DEM processing The Shuttle Radar Topography Mission (SRTM) is a joint project between the National Geospatial-Intelligence Agency (NGA) and the National Aeronautics and Space Administration (NASA). With data points every 1 arc-second, SRTM successfully gathered radar data across 80 per cent of the Earth's land surface between 60° north and 56° south latitude (EROS, 2018). The principle of the SRTM is interferometry which is researched from two sets of radar signals. The primary antennas in the Shuttle's payload compartment can both send and receive radar echoes, but the supplemental antennae at the end of a retractable 60-meter pole can only receive them. Accurate elevation of the Earth's surface may be computed using information about the distance between the two antennas and changes in the reflected radar wave signals. The data we use is SRTM1(1 arc-second) whose accuracy is 30 m. in order to get the same area of the ASTER data, using ENVI to set the projection and save the image as tiff. After that, we can import the tiff into the ArcGIS pro and make a new polygon feature that covers the area on the map. Then export the feature to the shapefile. We can upload this file to USGS to get the study area and download the SRTM1 dem from the USGS. The SRTM we download is a satellite image covering our region, not the same as our region. We need to combine the image using ENVI mosaicking tools to clip our region from the whole image. Then Change the projection of ASTER data to WGS 84 which is the same as the SRTM data. After that, we can use the ArcGIS pro’s extract from mask tools, to extract the same region of ASTER dem from the SRTM data. Finally, because the spatial resolution of the DEM is not the same, the comparison should be at the same scale. To compare them, The ASTER DEM was scaled up to an aggregated pixel size that matched the SRTM grid’s proportions by using the resampling method in ArcGIS pro (Nikolakopoulos, 2006). Figure 2.2.2 shows this process. Figure 2.2.2 ### 2.3 ASTER SRTM DEM comparison Now we have two DEMs of ASTER and SRTM1 in the same region and the same spatial resolution. Pearson and Spearman correlation coefficients were determined for the elevations as well as the slope obtained from them to determine the degree of connection between the ASTER and SRTM DEMs. Pearson's correlation coefficient denotes the relationship between two variables, or the degree of covariation between the two variables, or the tendency for two variables to vary together in the sense that one increases as the other increases (positive covariation), or one variable increases as the other decreases (negative covariation) (Nikolakopoulos, 2006). We calculate the correlation matrix about the DEM and their slope in this article. Skewness and kurtosis were also used to compare their distribution. The skewness measures the asymmetry of the probability distribution of a random variable and is a measure of the degree of asymmetry with respect to the mean. The skewness of the normal distribution is 0, that is, the data distribution is symmetrical, and the skewness is 0. If the skewness is greater than positive, there is a long tail on the right; if the skewness is less than 0, it is negative, and there is a long tail on the left; at the same time, the greater the absolute value of the skewness, the more serious the deviation of the distribution. Kurtosis is a statistic that studies the steepness or smoothness of the data distribution. By measuring the kurtosis coefficient, we can determine whether the data is steeper or smoother relative to the normal distribution. The greater the kurtosis, the higher and the sharper the distribution is. Furthermore, the root means square error (RMSE) is a widely used statistic for assessing vertical accuracy in Dems The root mean square error (RMSE) is a composite error statistic that accounts for both random and systematic mistakes that occur during data collection. The USGS use the RMSE technique to assess DEM results by comparing them to elevation points that represent the “most likely” elevation for a specific site. The RMSE of the SRTM DEM was determined in this study in comparison to a reference DEM (ASTER DEM) (Nikolakopoulos, 2006). In this article, the IDL is used to calculate the RMSE. Export the difference of DEM through the ArcGIS pro to simplify the process. Then compare their slope difference. 3. Results and Analysis3.1 CorrelationFigure 3.1 and figure 3.2 show the distribution of ASTER and SRTM. The ASTER distribution is not particularly compatible with normal distribution while it retains the same pattern as the SRTM. The peak value of ASTER appears between 2282 and 2354 while SRTM appears between 2346 and 2428. From the range of two DEMs, we know that the ASTER DEM is offset to the left. Figure 3.1 distribution of ASTER Figure 3.2 distribution of SRTM Table 3.1 shows the summary statistics for ASTER‐ and SRTM‐derived elevation and slope for both study areas. The difference of the mean value is 22m. The difference in min value is 54m and in max value is 270m. The max slope difference also has 6 degrees. It appears that the distributions derived from the two DEMS are of the same shape regarding symmetry and fat-tailedness since the skewness and kurtosis are closer in small difference. Table 3.1 statistic measures of ASTER and SRTM Figure 3.2 shows the correlation between elevation and slope. We can see that the elevation between SRTM and ASTER DEM show a substantial strong positive correlation, which is 0.9859. The slope correlation value is less than that at 0.4012, but still positively correlated. relation elevation slope Correlation 0.9859 0.4012 Table 3.2 correlation of elevation and slope 3.2 Difference The figure shows the difference between SRTM and ASTER which is come from the SRTM subtracting the ASTER. The white colour means the bigger value. From this image, it can be observed that most of the high differences occur at the top of the mountain, and the largest value of this image is 1284. The histogram shows in figure 3.4. Its skewness is 3.8 and kurtosis is 49.7 which show the differences are concentrated. Its RMSE is 3.89 m. those show that two DEMs although the difference may be large in some pixels, the overall error does not hit. They have the same shape. Figure 3.3 Difference between SRTM and ASTER Figure 3.4 Distribution of difference (SRTM-ASTER DATA) 3.3 Slope Figures 3.6 and 3.7 show the slope distribution of two DEMs. The standard deviation of the ASTER slope is larger than the SRTM slope. That means the SRTM is gentler than ASTER which shows the ASTER DEM has more noise. Figure 3.5 shows the slope of two DEMs, the left is ASTER’s slope and the right is SRTM’s slope. The mean of ASTER is higher than the SRTM. From this comparison, we can see that the SRTM is smoother than ASTER. Figure 3.5 slope of ASTER(left) and SRTM(right) Figure 3.6 Slope of ASTER Figure 3.7 Slope of SRTM Figure 3.8 shows the difference of slope between two DEMs, the white is the high value which is ASTER subtract SRTM. The image shows that the big difference mostly appears at the top of the mountain. But at some ground place, there also have the white pixel, which means the ASTER still have a large slope in the ground. The skewness is 0.25 and the kurtosis is 4.95. The slope difference is very symmetrical, the kurtosis is big means error is concentrated. Figure 3.8 slope difference (ASTER-SRTM) Figure 3.9 slope difference histogram ## 4. Conclusion The goal of this paper was to compare the difference of DEMs derived from the ASTER stereo image by ENVI wizard and SRTM DEM downloaded from the USGS website. In this article, we use ASTER DEM to clip the bigger SRTM DEM, so there is no displacement problem in this method. The limitation of this method is in the correlation, the Pearson can be used to give more evidence. And in the slope part, a comparison between slope and curvature can make this method more dimensions. The difference between two DEMs is produced by SRTM subtracting ASTER. The mean difference is 22m. the corresponding frequency histogram indicated that the ASTER elevation was underestimated. The comparison of SRTM and ASTER DEMs allowed for a qualitative evaluation of the horizontal and vertical components of the inaccuracy, while statistical techniques were utilized to determine vertical accuracy. We use skewness and kurtosis to compare the elevation distribution. The two DEMs has a similar shape regarding symmetry and fat-tailedness also in the slope distribution. The correlation of the elevation is 0.9 which indicates that the elevation of two DEMs is strongly correlated. The slope correlation is 0.4 which also shows the correlation between two DEMs’ slopes. For this reason, these two datasets have a strong correlation. The aster DEM has an overall small range and is visually noticeably noisy. The slope map SRTM is smoother and has a smaller standard deviation. The RMSE value of the two DEMs is 3.89m, which is a good result, proving that the corresponding difference between the two DEMs is not large, indicating that although the ranges are offset, the overall trend of the same distribution. ReferenceZhou, Q., 2017. Digital elevation model and digital surface model. posts.title: 水资源短缺指数分析--英国
posts.text: 摘要通过可用数据，估计英国缺水指数南安普顿大学，地理信息与环境专业，core skills in GIS第二次作业 The water scarcity in The United Kingdom1.IntroductionWater scarcity, defined as a lack of availability to acceptable quantities of water for human and environmental purposes, is rapidly being recognized as a severe and developing challenge in many countries (Chris, 2012). The population of the world, the life quality improvement and the irrigated agriculture expansion all request more water to the society in the past decade (Mekonnen, 2016).The global hydrological cycle yearly provides several times fresher water than is required to support the world’s current population of approximately six billion (~6*109) people. But the distribution of most water is not average and cannot be used for us (Postel, 2000). In the future decades, water will be a major limitation for agriculture, necessitating major institutional changes, notably in Asia and Africa (Rijsberman, 2006). A variety of indexes have been created during the last 20 years to quantify the sensitivity of water resources to resource fragility. The most common index is the Falkenmark index used to measure the level of water scarcity. They use the 1700 m3 of renewable water resources per year per capita to present the threshold, which is estimated the requirements of the household, agricultural, industrial and energy sectors (Rijsberman, 2006). An absolute water shortage occurs when the index threshold is less than 500 m3/person/year, and no stress occurs when the index threshold is larger than 1700 m3/person/year (Falkenmark, 1989). Here are also two indices based on human water requirements. The Gleick define water scarcity by determining whether the water supply meets basic human needs, such as drinking water for survival, water for hygiene, sanitation services and household. All use the basic standard to get the 50 litres per person per day threshold (Gleick, 1996). Ohlsson construct a water scarcity index called Social Water Scarcity Index (SWSI). SWSI is calculated by using the first-generation waster scarcity index which measures the availability of renewable freshwater per capita to divide the Human Development Index (HDI). It can not only show the importance of the society’s adaptive ability facing water scarcity, but also avoid the anomalies value in the first-generation index (OhIsson, 2000). Some people analyze water scarcity by the water footprinting. On a local or regional basis, water footprint (WF) indicators can quantify the amount of water utilised in a certain river basin or from an aquifer. Bluewater footprint is consumed by humans from blue water resources. And the volume of surface and groundwater consumed as a result of the creation of goods or services can be used to calculate the blue water footprint (Veettil, 2018). ‘ Green water footprint refers to the amount of water from precipitation that, after having been stored in the root zone of the soil (green water), is either lost by evapotranspiration or incorporated by plants. It is particularly relevant for agricultural, horticultural and forestry products.’ (Wikimedia Foundation, 2021) Agricultural, biofuel, and forestry products all have a green water footprint. The use of the water footprint idea is fast expanding in a variety of industries (Veettil, 2018). 2.Method2.1 Study AreaThe study area is the United Kingdom shown in figure 2.1. The total area is 93628 square miles (242500 km2), with an estimated population in 2020 of 68 million. Agriculture in the United Kingdom uses the country’s land area. Sheep provide most of the British wool, with only a few goats or alpacas cultivated for exotic wools like cashmere or angora. Cattle provide the bulk of milk, and hens provide most eggs. Figure 2.1 2.2 Theory And Data prepareThe Falkenmark index is the widely used index. Because it is easy to get the relative data. However, its main limitations are obvious: (a) it fails to take enough environmental and social factors into account, thus it’s not convincing even as an indicator of physical scarcity; (b) the identification of the threshold is too arbitrary (Rijsberman, 2006). It depends on two variables: surface runoff (m3/yr) and population. But the surface runoff often has a large scale of spatial resolution which can not be compared with the high resolution of population. In that case, we use the criticality ratio – the ratio of water withdrawals for human use to total renewable water resources (Rijsberman, 2006). The population, livestock and irrigated construct the water consumption. The threshold of value is 0.4 commonly used to determine the boundary of water stress. RI=(Population+livestock+irrigated)/(renewable water resource) the renewable freshwater resources per capita in the United Kingdom is 2195 m3 (ourworldindata, 2017). The population counts layer comes from the world pop website and is 1km resolution with WGS84. The irrigation data is downloaded from the food and agriculture organization (FAO) website with 5 minutes resolution and the data is expressed in hectares per cell. And the livestock data is from the FAO livestock system with 5 minutes of arc spatial resolution. We choose cattle, sheep, chicken, and pig as livestock variables. Gleick indicated that the human basis requirement of the water is 50 litres per person per day which is not influenced by the climate, technology, and culture (Gleick, 1996). From Knox, we know the total annual water use is 225 Mm3 (Knox, 2020) (616.4 m3 per day). The water consumption comes from Ward’s research. The average typical water requirement of cattle is 40 L/day, sheep is 6L/day, chicken is 300 L/1000 birds/day, and the pig is 9 L/day (Ward, 2007). 2.3 MethodologyFor the first, we need to make them in the same projection. And as the maps we get are all the worldwide, we need to clip them into England region. Using the Extract by mask tool in ArcGIS pro.Extract by mask extract the UK irrigation from the world. Because the resolution of livestock and irrigation is the same, we decide to make the population resolution the same as livestock resolution. In our method, we calculate the water consumption per person per day. We cannot use the resample tools, because that will change the population number in the region. Using the aggregate tool can generate the reduced-resolution raster image and the output cell can calculate the sum of the input cell that is contained in the output cell area. Now we have the same resolution maps and we need to combine the livestock layers. Using the raster calculator to do that with the formula ‘“cattle” *40 + “chicken” *0.3 + “sheep” *6 + “pig” 9’. This is the four species’ water consumption per day. And the population layer multiplies 50 get the map layer of human consumption and multiply the renewable water 21951000/365 (per day) get the map layer of renewable water resource. Using irrigation to multiply the usage in irrigation gets the irrigation consumption map. Next, we combine the three variable layers using the raster calculator. And get the final result RI. When the RI is under 20% means this place is rich in water, and 20% - 40% may have pressure in water. Over 60% means have severe water scarce (Brown, 2011). This is not the same as brown’s saying. Because my formula denominator is the renewable water and he is the available water which is not the same as the renewable water. The processing of this method is below (figure 2.2). Figure 2.2 3.ResultHere is the result of the calculation. It shows that the north of the UK has severe water-scarce with a ratio is greater than 0.4. someplace the ratio is even greater than 1 which is not a good result. And in the south region, the most place is under the green colour, which means the water is adequate. Because the renewable data is calculated by population to multiply renewable water per capita, it makes the water’s distribution follow the population. In that case, in the north place where the people are less and the livestock and irrigation are much more, it will appear the ratio greater than 1. In the south region, the livestock and irrigation are less than in the north and the population is much more, so the water is rich in the south. The red place in the southwest corner is the area with the most livestock, but the population distribution is more scattered. Figure 3.1 water scarcity index of criticality ratios This histogram shows the statistic of water scarcity index, we can see that most pixels are less than 0.2 which means no pressure in water using. Only a few greater than the 0.4, and the pixels greater than 0.8 are much less. The mean is 0.1. From those we can know that the average of the United Kingdom water scarcity is under 0.2, rich in water. A few regions in the water-scarce. Figure 3.2 Distribution of water scarcity index Discussion For this method, we do not consider the distribution of the water on the geography side, because the data we have is the renewable water per capita, we just use this to multiply the population, which means more people, more water. It will lead to a result that the water distribution follows population distribution. The strength of this method is it does not consider the environmental impact on the water resource, which may make the calculation complexes. We just focus on the variables we input and how their relationship led to the result. However, when this method avoids the different requirements in the different situations, it still has limitations: Renewable water is based on the river and rainfall, not considered the man-made water supply (desalination or recycle water). It ignores countries’ ability to adjust to reduced water supplies through behavioural changes or new technology (Chris, 2012). The distribution of renewable water may not be the real distribution based on the population. The data on water withdrawals do not account for how much of it is consumed (or evapotranspired) and how much is available for recycling through return flows (Damkjaer, 2017). This method can be improved by changing the data source, such as using the renewable water distribution map, not just the number per capita. And add the industry water consumption to make this method better with different data types. referenceChris W. Understanding water scarcity: Definitions and measurements.
